documents.t: Downloading Your Android App for Android
Build and deploy native mobile apps for iOS and Android with Buzztouch.

Normal paragraph with <breaking syntax> List item 1 is normal List item 2 has <syntax> which causes issues for the html parser (& what about : / \ [ ] { } ; “ ‘)?! See https://github.com/sillsdev/docu-notion/issues/21 What about a link with <angle brackets>?

This page is special in that it exists in the outline rather than the database where we prefer pages to live. It is here to demonstrate that docu-notion will still retrieve it. This is a raw link to the intro: Getting Started This is a raw link to the fruits section: [Problem Internal Link] This is a link to Apples. This is a bare to google https://www.google.com/

note These instructions were written for Buzztouch 5.0 for Android.

Download Android Studio https://developer.android.com/studio (Choose Intel Mac or Apple Silicon Mac depending on which you have) Open .dmg you downloaded and drag Android Studio to the Applications folder. Navigate to your Applications folder and open Android Studio. Gatekeeper may prompt you to confirm you want to open it. When opening for the first time, Android Studio will ask you to if you’d like to import any existing installation or config. In my case I didn’t have an existing configuration… so I left Do not import settings selected and clicked OK to proceed. I opted out of sharing analytics by choosing the Don’t send option. Android Studio will open an Auto Setup Wizard. We’ll walk through the following steps Click Next Standard is auto-selected, click Next Choose your preferred theme, then click Next Once complete, Android Studios will prompt to verify your Settings. Click Next to proceed You will be prompted to accept the License Agreement. Select the Accept radio button, then press Finish to begin installation. Components will begin downloading… Once complete, the Android Studio Welcome pane will open.

Visit the Download Project page for your Buzztouch application Select the [Android Beta] Buzztouch Core v5.0.0 build version, then click Package Android Studio Project. Once the packaging is complete, download your project.
documents.s: Downloading Your Android App for Android

documents.t: Unzip your Android Studio project, then drag your Buzztouch project folder on to the Android Studio app icon. You may be prompted to allow Android Studio to access your downloads folder. If prompted, click Trust Project to allow your project to open in Android Studio. Your project will begin loading… you will see several Grade configurations downloading in the bottom right hand corner.

Under the Tools menu select Device Manager In the sidebar pane that opens, click the Create device button. The Virtual Device Configuration window will open. In this case, I chose the Pixel 6 Pro. Click Next to begin installation. Android Studio will request you choose an System Image (operating system) to install on the Emulator. I chose UpsideDownCake, (you may want to pick a previous version such as Tiramisu if you aren’t comfortable modifying your gradle config). If the image is not installed you will not be able to click the Next button, instead click the download icon next to the Release Name. This will bring up the SDK Component Installer. You must agree to the license agreement to install the operating system. Choose Accept then click Next to continue. Once the install is complete, click Finish to close the dialog You can now use the System Image you installed on the emulator. Click Next to proceed. If you’d like you can name your AVD (Android Virtual Device). I left mine with the default name. Click Finish to create the emulator. Once the emulator is installed, you can click the ▶ icon to build and run your project on the Android Virtual Device. Note: I had to slightly adjust my gradle configuration to get the project to run on UpsideDownCake. You may have more success running your project on an older version of Android.
If you embed a gif in notion, it should be embedded in Docusaurus

When it detects an embedded gif, docu-notion does the following: Adds a import GifPlayer from "react-gif-player"; to the markdown. Inserts html like <GifPlayer gif="https://media.giphy.com/media/VhiAuDYHkNPydiNnOs/giphy.gif" /> info If your site is not based on docu-notion-sample-site, you may need to add react-gif-player to your Docusaurus project: yarn add react-gif-player or npm i react-gif-player
This page is here to test what url we end up with when we have a character like “/” that has meaning in URLs. An example of a fruit is Apples are good
This page is here to test what url we end up with when we have a character like “/” that has meaning in URLs. An example of a fruit is Apples are good

one two Some text in between three this is three aa four This is a bulleted list: alpha beta A todo item Another todo item (note, with Docusaurus 2, if you follow the above list with the below toggle without material in-between, you get https://github.com/sillsdev/docu-notion/issues/77) toggle me - inside bullet inside plain text This is a toggle The inside of a toggle This is an empty toggle

If docu-notion notices that you have embedded a video, it should convert that to code useable in Docusaurus by using react-player. YouTube example: docu-notion does the following when it detects an embedded link to a video: Adds import ReactPlayer from "react-player"; to the markdown Inserts html like <ReactPlayer controls url="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5M3nJrlf3p0&t=70s" /> info If your site is not based on docu-notion-sample-site, you may need to add ReactPlayer to your Docusaurus project: yarn add react-player or npm i react-player If docu-notion notices that you have embed a video it should convert that to code useable in Docusaurus by using react-player. Docusaurus has some nice custom callouts called “Admonitions”. note Note about something tip Tip about something with an internal link. info Info about something caution A Caution about something danger Something dangerous ← should be bold :::🚧 A note about this being under construction :::
